review_title: Just a temporary place to hold over

pros: Faith oriented higher education community

pros: Students workers are able to prioritize academics and the community is hospitable.
cons: Often, only Federal Work Study eligible students can be hired for these minimum wage positions.

pros: tight knit community that's very supportive
cons: can be a little disorganized at times

review_title: Playing the role of a puppet
pros: At the time I was working at Benu, the benefits were fully covered, employees had a great plan for tuition remission for undergrad and graduate degrees, vacation/sick/personal/floating days were more than I had ever seen in an organization and a few of my co-workers (who continue to be underpaid and under appreciated!)
cons: Where do I begin!? Before accepting a job at Benedi tine please read these reviews and don't take them lightly. Although many of them may seem over dramatic and ridiculous, their a true look at how this organization runs and how they treat their emplyees. Major con would definitely be compensation - if you're a 22 yr old graduate, still living with your parents, have no rent/loans/car payments and are looking to put something on a resume, then this is the place to start. But if you are trying to support a family and need something that will lead to bigger and better things this is not it! Every single department is stuck in their own egotistical struggle and hate to see new talent come in and want to better the system. I can't say how happy I am to have gotten a few years under my belt, my graduate degree and to have gotten the hell out of here!

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Lisle, IL
pros: Great Staff to work with
cons: Boring sometimes because of the staff

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Lisle, IL
pros:
Vacation time(lots ) 
Cafeteria food is great
cons: No one ever knows what’s going on

pros: There used to be a lot of pros; there aren't any pros any longer.  The University doesn't follow the Benedictine values that they espouse.  Employee loyalty to the students and the community means nothing.
cons:
The environment is toxic and when upper management is advised of situations that could be unhealthy or detrimental to the University's overall security and well being they ignore them. 

Employees who have gone above and beyond in taking care of their teams , helping the community and have a strong commitment to the University are forced out or terminated.  

The current housecleaning intended to get the University's funds back into the black is a failure.  The administrative side of the house is woefully understaffed and cannot keep up with the demands of the University despite the continuing waning enrollment..

The benefits that once were good are being whittled away at bit by bit.   The facilities are not being kept up and the equipment is old.  People can't work without the proper tools nor can students be attracted to enroll.

This was once a really wonderful place to work.

review_title: Great benefits, no room for growth
pros: Benefits--complete health insurance coverage; several weeks of PTO: a week off at Christmas & New Year's as a gift from the president, catholic holidays, snow days, etc. Complete tuition reimbursement.
cons: Staff are not held accountable by senior management and take advantage of the extensive sick & vacation time.  New ideas and growth are stifled by staff due to a "don't step on anyone's toes" mentality.  Most staff stick around for years solely because of the benefit package, and have no real passion or drive to succeed, which is discouraging to new employees and younger staff members.

pros:
The university has fantastic employees! I enjoy everyone that I work with and that is something you can't find everywhere. There is a strong sense of community where the faculty and staff care about the students. We know many students by their names and the students themselves are just awesome. 

The time off is AMAZING! The benefits are AWESOME! Fantastic community!

The school is pushing for excellence. I can see how the new management is driving for excellence and change is good!
cons:
Salaries are a little on the low side, but they make up for it with the benefits and time off.  

Some employees are having trouble adapting to change, they need to look at it as a chance for growth and time to improve old ways of doing things.

review_title: Fiscal Crisis: Will we even survive?
pros: Benedictine was an amazing community. I say 'was' because it is no longer somewhere I would want to work.  I have begun to look for employment elsewhere.
cons:
In the last five years there has been a COMPLETE change in upper management; from a new President down to lower managerial staff, all brought in by the new president or to replace those forced out.   Whole departments have been eliminated [marketing] or reduced [facilities, business, academic support, student life] and are not replaced. There is no upwards mobility.

As of this week (May 18th) we were told staff is being laid off in an attempt to get control of our FIVE MILLION dollar short fall in the budget. We've come in under-enrolled for the last four years which has been publicly reported by our student newspaper.   Students are not enrolling; they drive the community and budget.  Transfer students enrollment has dropped off a cliff with no explanation.   

Benefits, once great, have been chipped away year after year. Health care costs have gone up and the 403b seven percent match being reduced.  These benefits made up for the lower pay which is still not being addressed despite a "salary study" being conducted.  I believe this was done under the guise of improving pay when it was used to find people to eliminate.

Those that remain will get more work with no increase in pay. Morale is, frankly, at an all time low.  It is hard to come to work and put on a brave face when the job itself feels like a exercise in futility. 

I love BenU but I fear its days are numbered.

review_title: Very positive community and loved the opportunity to work with students and alumni!
pros: Healthcare benefits started the first day worked, office culture fun and encouraging, individuals were promoted from within,  ability to continue education, cafeteria on campus was convenient and offered healthy choices.  Values were implemented throughout and training was excellent.  Friendly staffers and upbeat atmosphere.
cons: Depending on which department worked in, work-life balance could be difficult but changes in leadership within the department corrected that although a little too late for some.  As it is a Catholic not for profit, salaries could be better but the time off and benefits balanced that area as well.

pros:
Get to work any events going on at the school. 
Managers all seemed to be very laid back and understanding, especially if you had issues with needing time to complete your schoolwork instead of work.
Very easy to get another student to fill in for you.
cons:
If you are a student, it can get in the way of your schoolwork, but really thats any job.
You typically have to work until well after each event and thing like sports can go into many overtimes keeping you there much longer than expected.

review_title: Great People, Family Environment, Great Benefits
pros: Benedictine University is a great place to work. They especially take take you in terms of the benefits that they offer (i.e. tuition remission, time off, etc.) They have created a family like atmosphere in the tradition of Benedictine.
cons: The compensation is not that great, but I believe that is due to the amazing benefits package that they offer. Other than that, I really have no complaints.

pros: Benefits. I have nothing else to add.
cons:
I was excited to work with Benedictine but didn't realize that I would be walking into a high school environment all over again. You would think that others in the office would be too busy to watch and analyze the new hire, then gossip. 

You also have to worry about stepping on other department's toes rather than working together. The 'stepping on toes' is a result of conflicts that date back before most current employees were hired. This hinders in taking initiative which seems to be in every job description. It's quite laughable. 

Don't dare to have a mind of your own or your own opinion, you'll be looking for another job in no time. Smile, nod and tell others what they'd like to hear if you cannot find a job anywhere else. Don't dare to have a personality of your own. Meetings on how to change your personality will be scheduled. My best advice is to leave your brain and who you really are at home. You won't need it! Also, get use to having your ideas stolen, it's the norm.

Benedictine promotes subject matters and not good quality managers. It is common for employees at Benedictine to be a victim of an inexperienced manager. This may result in being let go or punished by being ignored and finger pointing.

Being a university, you would think that proper office protocols are put into place. New hires shouldn't have to create them.

There are also too many cooks in the kitchen. I don't see how several departments get anywhere.

The best thing about Benedictine are the benefits. If you decide to apply, good luck! The corporate world is easier than this place!

pros:
A lot of time off.
Great people to work with.
Fairly laid back working environment.
cons:
Higher ups don't take care of their employees.
They are always saying how much they want to grow but not willing do to the things necessary to do so.
A lot of broken promises.
Terribly low pay.
Work long hours

pros: Community is very welcoming and supportive. Tenure track faculty are supported, and encouraged, not initiated. I regularly feel valued, respected, and needed.
cons: The university is riddled with archaic broken systems. Many systems are easily 15 years outdated. Many tasks that are automated at other peer institutions are completed with "paper and pencil" requiring several hours per week of busy work that should be done in a matter of minutes. The reliance on manual entry and editing results in numerous errors and repeating tasks that could have been avoided. Lost time and the inability to director effort into innovation is the norm here.

pros: Great work-life balance here at Benedictine. Full time employees get a very generous amount of time off and great insurance benefits. The community of employees (faculty and staff alike) are all very friendly and care very much about the school. Its nice to be in a place that outwardly cares for their employees. Likewise, its a very laid back atmosphere.
cons: As with any job, you tend to get more responsibility without any additional pay. Benedictine pays great benefits as a way to overcompensate for their below market salaries. As a healthy person, I'd rather see a little more on the paycheck.

review_title: BenU is simply a great place to work!
pros: Being apart of the learning process at a mission based organization, from traditional, graduate, and doctoral level students, is amazing. It is wonderful to experience the people and energy of a beautiful suburban college campus every day.  It is exciting and rewarding to be apart of BenU in 2020 and beyond!
cons: There are challenges similar to high education locally and across the country , but with those challenges comes rewarding opportunities!

pros: Decent benefits. Lots of PSV time and holidays. Good work/life balance. Tuition remission, but only cover about $5,000 each year.
cons: Very low pay. Just like any other business, the university's higher ups get ton of bonuses but don't want to give their workers raises. A raise is maybe 5-15 cents more each hour, if you're lucky. There's no room for advancement. Also, they should offer better tuition remission.

pros: Great benefits. free school, great amount of vacation/personal time off. and they match 403b up to 7%.
cons: They don't care about the little guys. They only care about the upper mgmt.

pros: Collaborative, friendly, and efficient staff, professors and department heads.  Extremely supportive management - great flexibility and students eager and excited to learn.
cons: Adjuncts just starting out have very little "prep" work or explanation - this is a positive or a negative depending on how self-sufficient you are, but it took awhile to figure out whether I was doing this "right".

pros: Wonderful coworkers, engaged students, safe campus.
cons: Grossly underpaid. Salaries not competitive or consistent with job responsibilities. Caseload of students is ridiculous - no way can an advisor keep up on all students. No real opportunity for advancement. Lacking strong leadership at the top.

review_title: Great sense of community, incredible benefits, grossly underpaid.
job_title: Coordinator of MSN Program Operations in Lisle, IL
pros: Ample time off. All major holidays and even some Catholic holidays like "Easter Monday." University absorbs all costs of health, dental, and vision. My position allows me to have a very flexible work schedule.
cons: My only major con is that the university pays their employees well under market.

pros: They pay was good and the staff was friendly to work with. I enjoyed working here a lot. It was a great job for a student. I really improved my customer service skills.
cons: Work was tedious and it was hard to stay focus on work with all of the students who came in to the lobby of the library. Having the IT department in the library was a gift and a curse.

review_title: So many better choices in higher ed
pros: I really like my coworkers and like the work itself. That's it.
cons: Too many to include. Will be surprised if we are accepting students after this year. The culture has changed so much over this past year. It isn't fun anymore. If you are going to make half of what other people are making at other universities, you have to love the mission, make a reasonable amount of money, or at least enjoy it enough to overlook the ridiculously low salaries.  Am looking for other work with a better future.

pros: It's nice walking around the main campus outside during the summer. A few close co-workers were very welcoming and informative.
cons: The University pays their employees very low for the work they're expected to do. Management doesn't treat most of their employees with respect, which makes it a very toxic work environment. I'm glad that I got out of there when I did because they're going downhill fast. It's extremely unfortunate that the students aren't getting the care they deserve.

pros: Hopefully you like your co-workers, because there's not much to like beyond that.
cons: Employees are treated poorly, not respected for their knowledge and profession. The new administration has really sunk the university to a new low. It's been very sad watching my former co-workers being treated like they don't know anything, being blamed for results they warned against and had nothing to do with the outcomes, and then being let go. BenU has become a demoralizing place to work. If you value your dignity, look elsewhere.

review_title: They would never survive in the real world
pros: Benefits are pretty good for this day and age. My medical was covered by the university.
cons: Low, low wages. No mobility. Get your free degree and go.

pros: Some really good co-workers and pretty good PTO and other benefits.
cons: Employees are not compensated even close to fairly across the board. On top of that, management treats employees as worthless and disposable, and it shows in the employee morale. Since the new president has taken over, this trend has continued at an exclerated rate as the University’s financial woes worsen.

job_title: Sports Information Assistant in Arlington Heights, IL
pros: Work with people who are passionate about sports and helping student-athletes reach their full potentials. Fun environment, everyone is very friendly and make work a joy.
cons: Make minimum wage as a student worker and work depends on when home athletic games take place.

pros: You will find out how strong you are and who your real friends are. You make great friends going through hell together.
cons: You are not good enough even after years of great reviews and multiple promotions. Extremely toxic environment.

pros: Fun atmosphere but also professional

pros:

job_title: Seasonal Maintenance Worker in Chicago, IL
pros: Great Staff... Very friendly and flexible
cons: None. All around great experience

pros: Individual team relationships were strong, felt like an extended family.
cons: Toxic environment. A more reactive than proactive decision-making strategy. Senior leadership seemed corrupt. Employees are jumping ship like crazy, or being let go.

pros: The people who worked at the local campus were friendly and hard-working.

review_title: Great place to work if you are just entering the work field.
